page.title: 01HILLS EAST OF CRAVEN ARMS
page.content: Part of the limestone Wenlock Edge, running NE-SW and reaching a height of 334m at Callow Hill and 290m at Norton Camp to the southwest. There is not much surface water, but a streat breaks through the scarp and one of two streams, flowing off the dip slope, is at the lowest point, about 120m in the southeast corner. The few valleys in this rolling area are used by 2 lanes which are linked by another, below and parallel to the higher of the 2 scarp faces. Castle Road, the B4368 from Craven Arms to Bridgnorth, uses another valley, attains a height of 170m and maintains this on the dip. There is a hamlet at one of the lane junctions and most of the other farms and cottages, some of stone, lie along the B road; it is thinly populated. The farming is mainly arable - cereals and turnips -
